## Description {#details}

LLVM <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> Representation.

This is a very important LLVM class. It is the base class of all values computed by a program that may be used as operands to other values. <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> is the super class of other important classes such as <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instruction">Instruction</a> and <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/function">Function</a>. All Values have a <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/type">Type</a>. <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/type">Type</a> is not a subclass of <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a>. Some values can have a name and they belong to some <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/module">Module</a>. Setting the name on the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> automatically updates the module&#39;s symbol table.

Every value has a &quot;use list&quot; that keeps track of which other Values are using this <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a>. A <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> can also have an arbitrary number of ValueHandle objects that watch it and listen to RAUW and Destroy events. See <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/valuehandle-h">llvm/IR/ValueHandle.h</a> for details.

Definition at line 74 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/value-h">Value.h</a>.

## Enumerations

### anonymous enum  {#a19833a77591e9d860373ab7fc4793044}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="anonymous enum : unsigned"
 labels = {["protected"]}>
The number of operands in the subclass.

<EnumerationList title="Enumeration values">

<Link id="a19833a77591e9d860373ab7fc4793044a6050aee72ddd23b6d91ec3f126679fec" />
<EnumerationListItem name="NumUserOperandsBits">
 (= 27)
</EnumerationListItem>

</EnumerationList>

This member is defined by this class, but not used for anything. Subclasses can use it to store their number of operands, if they have any.

This is stored here to save space in <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/user">User</a> on 64-bit hosts. Since most instances of <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> have operands, 32-bit hosts aren&#39;t significantly affected.

Note, this should <em>NOT</em> be used directly by any class other than <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/user">User</a>. <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/user">User</a> uses this value to find the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/use">Use</a> list.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/value-h/#l00107">107</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/value-h">Value.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

Concrete subclass of this.

An enumeration for keeping track of the concrete subclass of <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> that is actually instantiated. ## Protected Destructor

### ~Value() {#a3a578f458da8a4ab67052dba0f7bffdd}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="Value::~Value ()"
  labels = {["protected"]}>
<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a>&#39;s destructor should be virtual by design, but that would require that <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> and all of its subclasses have a vtable that effectively duplicates the information in the value <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/callingconv/#abdf8cf606905c10634e831390981b0ed">ID</a>.

As a size optimization, the destructor has been protected, and the caller should manually call deleteValue.

### getPointerDereferenceableBytes() {#acfdc7354dccb27bc092d9ac8c92b76c7}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>uint64&#95;t Value::getPointerDereferenceableBytes (<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/datalayout">DataLayout</a> &amp; DL, bool &amp; CanBeNull, bool &amp; CanBeFreed) const</>}>
Returns the number of bytes known to be dereferenceable for the pointer value.

If CanBeNull is set by this function the pointer can either be null or be dereferenceable up to the returned number of bytes.

IF CanBeFreed is true, the pointer is known to be dereferenceable at point of definition only. Caller must prove that allocation is not deallocated between point of definition and use.

### hasOneUser() {#a2e987c6af902aad6baa39bd5b7ef322c}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="bool Value::hasOneUser () const">
Return true if there is exactly one user of this value.

Note that this is not the same as &quot;has one use&quot;. If a value has one use, then there certainly is a single user. But if value has several uses, it is possible that all uses are in a single user, or not.

This check is potentially costly, since it requires traversing, in the worst case, the whole use list of a value.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/value-h/#l00452">452</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/value-h">Value.h</a>, definition at line 157 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/sandboxir/value-cpp">Value.cpp</a>.

### stripAndAccumulateConstantOffsets() {#a23c582e2452eeb2b2cf6e0c43eca617e}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>const Value &#42; llvm::Value::stripAndAccumulateConstantOffsets (<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/datalayout">DataLayout</a> &amp; DL, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> &amp; Offset, bool AllowNonInbounds, bool AllowInvariantGroup=false, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/function-ref">function&#95;ref</a>&lt; bool(<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> &amp;<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a>, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> &amp;<a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/#a05f5b9a11bdcc5feba62899f95dcf878a3134224cba2545bc57954d3b072aebb4">Offset</a>)&gt; ExternalAnalysis=nullptr) const</>}>
Accumulate the constant offset this value has compared to a base pointer.

Only &#39;getelementptr&#39; instructions (GEPs) are accumulated but other instructions, e.g., casts, are stripped away as well. The accumulated constant offset is added to <code>Offset</code> and the base pointer is returned.

The <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> <code>Offset</code> has to have a bit-width equal to the IntPtr type for the address space of &#39;this&#39; pointer value, e.g., use DataLayout::getIndexTypeSizeInBits(Ty).

If <code>AllowNonInbounds</code> is true, offsets in GEPs are stripped and accumulated even if the GEP is not &quot;inbounds&quot;.

If <code>AllowInvariantGroup</code> is true then this method also looks through strip.invariant.group and launder.invariant.group intrinsics.

If <code>ExternalAnalysis</code> is provided it will be used to calculate a offset when a operand of GEP is not constant. For example, for a value <code>ExternalAnalysis</code> might try to calculate a lower bound. If <code>ExternalAnalysis</code> is successful, it should return true.

If this is called on a non-pointer value, it returns &#39;this&#39; and the <code>Offset</code> is not modified.

Note that this function will never return a nullptr. It will also never manipulate the <code>Offset</code> in a way that would not match the difference between the underlying value and the returned one. Thus, if no constant offset was found, the returned value is the underlying one and <code>Offset</code> is unchanged.

Definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/value-h/#l00721">721</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/ir/value-h">Value.h</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### stripAndAccumulateConstantOffsets() {#a551ea28693c8f39b40d76f5255ca930d}

Merge two lists together.

Merges <code>L</code> and <code>R</code> using <code>Cmp</code>. To enable stable sorts, always pushes &quot;equal&quot; items from L before items from R.


<SectionUser title="Returns">
the first element in the list.
</SectionUser>


:::info
Completely ignores <em>Use::Prev</em> (doesn&#39;t read, doesn&#39;t update).
:::

</MemberDefinition>

</SectionDefinition>

## Public Static Attributes

### MaxAlignmentExponent {#ab5941ebb386c8b46a569d1d8dbfe0c8c}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="unsigned llvm::Value::MaxAlignmentExponent = 32"
  labels = {["constexpr", "static"]}>
The maximum alignment for instructions.

This is the greatest alignment value supported by load, store, and alloca instructions, and global values.
